2-ntomo-mask.name: N’tomo Mask
2-ntomo-mask.fact: This mask is a symbol of protection and represents an ancient ancestor of the Bamana people of West Africa.

5-birchwood-box.name: Birchwood Box
5-birchwood-box.fact: This box was made out of birchbark by the Mi'kmaq people, in Nova Scotia, Canada.

7-naga-hat.name: Naga Hat
7-naga-hat.fact: Hats like this were worn by the Naga peoples of India and Myanmar and often symbolised power.

9-naga-axe.name: Naga Axe
9-naga-axe.fact: Special axes like this were used by the Naga peoples of north east India and north west Myanmar.

11-devil-fish-bag.name: Devilfish Bag
11-devil-fish-bag.fact: Octopuses feature in the myths of indigenous peoples of the Pacific northwest, who also knew them as Devilfish.

16-janus-headdress.name: Janus Headdress
16-janus-headdress.fact: Wearing headdresses like this whilst performing rituals is thought to connect living people with their ancestors’ spirits.

17-spirit-mask.name: Pacific North West Mask
17-spirit-mask.fact: The indigenous people of the Pacific North West use masks like this to make the supernatural world visible.

18-spirit-mask.name: Namibia Mask
18-spirit-mask.fact: Masks are important for rituals in traditional African cultures where people believe the wearer briefly turns into the mask spirit.

25-incense-burner.name: Incense Burner
25-incense-burner.fact: This shows an angry Buddhist deity that would protect the Tibetan Buddhist religion.

33-thunderbird-bowl.name: Thunderbird Bowl
33-thunderbird-bowl.fact: Thunderbird was a powerful spirit animal to the peoples of the Pacific Northwest, who believed it shot lightning from its eyes and made thunder with its wings.

43-nazca-pot.name: Nazca Pot
43-nazca-pot.fact: The Nazca people of Peru believed powerful nature sprits controlled many aspects of life and often painted them onto pots like this one.

47-roman-helmet-cheekpiece.name: Roman Helmet Cheekpiece
47-roman-helmet-cheekpiece.fact: This cheekpiece from a Roman helmet depicts one of the mythical twins, Castor or Pollux, who were renowned for their skill as horsemen.

48-roman-roof-tilewebm.name: Roman Tile
48-roman-roof-tilewebm.fact: A tile of the ninth legion who were stationed in York until they disappeared with almost no trace in about 120 AD.

58-griffin-head.name: Griffin Head
58-griffin-head.fact: An Etruscan griffin head that would originally have decorated a ceramic vessel.

60-artemis-statue.name: Artemis Statue
60-artemis-statue.fact: Artemis was revered as a fertility deity in the Greek city of Ephesus instead of the goddess of hunting.

64-quartz-chalcedony.name: Agate
64-quartz-chalcedony.fact: Red and pink Agate from the Cheviot Hills on the England/Scotland border.

72-devils-toenails.name: Devils Toenails
72-devils-toenails.fact: Fossilised extinct shellfish Gryphaea arcuata also known as devil's toenails have been used as charms to prevent rheumatism.

73-snake-stone.name: Snake Stone
73-snake-stone.fact: An ammonite fossil on which the head of a snake has been carved.

80-labyrinthodon.name: Labyrinthodon model
80-labyrinthodon.fact: A miniature plaster model of the fossil amphibian Labyrinthodon by Benjamin Waterhouse Hawkins.

94-white-watson-stone.name: White Watson Tablet
94-white-watson-stone.fact: A stone plaque in which polished rocks are arranged to represent the geology of Derbyshire as it was understood in 1800.

97-aquamarine.name: Aquamarine
97-aquamarine.fact: Aquamarine is the March Birthstone.   Aquamarine gems were believed to protect sailors.

105-topaz.name: Topaz
105-topaz.fact: Topaz is the November Birthstone.  In ancient times, topaz was said to ward off asthma and epilepsy.

109-kingfisher.name: Kingfisher
109-kingfisher.fact: The Romans thought kingsfishers built nests on water but they actually dig burrows in riverbanks and nest inside them.

110-red-panda-firefox.name: Red Panda
110-red-panda-firefox.fact: Red pandas are also know as fire foxes because of their striking red fur.

112-hippo-teeth.name: Hippo Tooth
112-hippo-teeth.fact: Hippo normally have 36 teeth, four more than humans, which they use to grind their diet of plants.

113-hyena-skull.name: Hyaena Skull
113-hyena-skull.fact: Hyaena are associated with witchcraft in parts of Africa and use their huge teeth to crunch up a diet including lots of bones.

115-horses-skull.name: Horse Skull
115-horses-skull.fact: Horses have distinctive skulls with a large triangular lower jaw to support muscles they need for grinding up the grass they eat.

118-toad-model.name: Model of a Toad
118-toad-model.fact: People once believed toads had stones in their head that could neutralise poison.

120-tiger-skull.name: Tiger Skull
120-tiger-skull.fact: Unike lions, tigers live and hunt alone so they have huge fangs to quickly throttle their prey by themselves.

124-raven.name: Raven
124-raven.fact: Ravens and their relatives are famously intelligent. Research has shown they have the problem-solving abilities of a seven year old child.

127-stork.name: White Stork
127-stork.fact: These birds fly north in spring to build huge nests, which are often close to people who admire their dedication to raising their young.

128-eagle-owl.name: Eagle Owl
128-eagle-owl.fact: Owls are almost silent in flight due to the shape of their feathers which reduces the noise created by air moving over the wing.

131-ibis.name: Sacred Ibis
131-ibis.fact: The Egyptian god Thoth was believed to have a human body but the head of an ibis.

132-cockerel.name: Cockerel
132-cockerel.fact: The large spurs on a cockerel's feet are used for fighting. It can jump high and kick out to give a nasty scratch.

136-egyptian-vulture.name: Egyptian Vulture
136-egyptian-vulture.fact: Egyptian pharoahs wore headresses showing the vulture god Nekhbet representing royal authority and watching over the land.

137-gryfalcon.name: Gyrfalcon
137-gryfalcon.fact: The largest species of falcon, which is white because it lives in the snowy arctic.

140-leopard-head.name: Leopard Head
140-leopard-head.fact: A secretive nocturnal predator, Leopards are seen as powerful, cunning and magical creatures in the mythology of many different cultures

141-wild-boar.name: Boar Head
141-wild-boar.fact: A male boar uses its large tusks to slash and stab during fights rather than to bite.

148-pipistrelle-bat.name: Pipistrelle Bats
148-pipistrelle-bat.fact: Pipistrelle bats are the smallest bat in Britain, weighing 5 grams about the same as a 20 pence coin.

149-bat.name: Fruit Bat
149-bat.fact: Unlike many other bats, fruit bats have large eyes and feed during the day.

150-dove.name: Dove
150-dove.fact: Once largely a Christian symbol of purity, white doves now symbolise peace in many cultures.

151-magpie.name: Magpie
151-magpie.fact: Although not completely black, Magpies are part of the same family of birds as crows, ravens, and jackdaws.

156-eider-duck.name: Eider Duck
156-eider-duck.fact: Saint Cuthbert is said to have miraculously sheltered eider ducks within his cloak while living as a hermit on the Farne Islands.

164-giant-australian-whelk.name: Giant Australian Whelk
164-giant-australian-whelk.fact: The giant whelk is the world's largest snail, growing up to 70 cm long.

165-giant-clam.name: Giant Clam
165-giant-clam.fact: The giant clam features in myths as a source of creation and abundance.

171-spider-in-a-box.name: Tarantula
171-spider-in-a-box.fact: In African mythologies, Anansi is the spider trickster who teaches valuable lessons about human nature.

178-dregs-of-silver.name: Dregs of Silver
178-dregs-of-silver.fact: Dregs from the extraction of silver from Galena (lead ore) between 1860 and 1870.

181-sunday-stone.name: Sunday Stone
181-sunday-stone.fact: Sunday Stone collected from an unknown location.

184-monkfish-skeleton.name: Monkfish Skeleton
184-monkfish-skeleton.fact: With its huge mouth, the monkfish has inspired tales of sea monsters in maritime folklore.
